leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.2] r 6.2 How proceedings commenced (cf SCR Part 4, rules 1 and 3, Part 7, rule 7; DCR Part 5, rules 5 and 6; LCR Part 5, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: How proceedings commenced (cf SCR Part 4, rules 1 and 3, Part 7, rule 7; DCR Part 5, rules 5 and 6; LCR Part 5, rule 1)

p.text: Subject to these rules, the practice notes and any other rules of court, a person may commence proceedings in the court by filing a statement of claim or a summons.
Subject to these rules, the practice notes and any other Act or law, the plaintiff may choose whether to commence proceedings by statement of claim or by summons.
Originating process must be served on each defendant.
An originating process served in accordance with subrule (3) must include the following:
the seal of the court on the first page (whether an original sealed copy or a photocopy of a sealed copy),
the case number or unique identifier,
the listing date (if allocated by the court registry).
[subr (3A) insrt Amendment 46 of 2011 Sch 1[2], effective 9 September 2011]
Subject to subrule (5), originating process is valid for service:
in the case of proceedings in the Supreme Court, the Land and Environment Court, the Dust Diseases Tribunal or the Local Court, for 6 months after the date on which it is filed, or
in the case of proceedings in the District Court:
except as provided by subparagraph (ii), for one month after the date on which it is filed, or
if the defendant (or at least one of the defendants) is to be served outside New South Wales, for 6 months after the date on which it is filed.
[subr (4) am Act 22 of 2005 s 5 and Sch 3, effective 1 June 2005 ; am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009 ; Amendment 28 of 2009 r 3, effective 18 September 2009]
Failure to serve originating process within the time limited by these rules does not prevent the plaintiff from commencing fresh proceedings by filing another originating process.
The approved forms are:
Statement of claim: Form 3A (where the filing party is legally represented) and Form 3B (where the filing party is acting in person or by authorised officer).
Summons: Form 4A (where the filing party is legally represented) and Form 4B (where the filing party is acting in person or by authorised officer).

The Statement of Claim or summons must identify the “type of claim” to which it relates. The relevant “types of claim” are listed in Pt 6 of the “Guide to Preparing Documents” on the UCPR website at www.lawlink.nsw.au/ucpr (or at any NSW court registry).
Legislation cited in [6.2.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 2, r 25.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 SCR Pt 79 r 8.

Despite the mandatory terms of the rule, there are circumstances where it will not rigidly apply. These include applications for urgent interlocutory relief under r 25 and proceedings commenced under particular local rules: eg, SCR Pt 79 r 8 (application by petition in electoral matters). The choice of originating process may also be influenced by the practice of the particular court, or division of the court, in which the proceedings are to be conducted. It is doubtful that the costs of proceedings are really likely to be substantially altered by the mere choice of originating process. This is particularly the case in the light of the court’s significant case management and directions powers: see, in particular, r 2 of the UCPR.
Legislation cited in [6.2.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.12.

The times for service provided for in the present rule apply notwithstanding any amendment of the originating process: Wakim v Coleman [2010] NSWCA 221; BC201006397 at [18] and [19]. Those times may be extended by a specific order (in the exercise of the power granted by UCPR r 1.12 ). The general principles relating to the exercise of that discretion are set out in [1.12.25] . The basic consideration is that the court is satisfied there is a proper (that is, good and sufficient) reason for the extension: FAI Insurances Ltd (in liq) v Mainprize [2006] NSWSC 554; BC200604204 (defendants aware of proceedings and involved in negotiations with plaintiff); Kleinwort Benson Ltd v Barbrak Ltd [1987] AC 597 ; Zhang v Zemin [2007] NSWSC 229; BC200701690 (delay in effecting service in China largely beyond the plaintiff’s control — claim for extension of limitation period — time for service extended by 6 months); Rich v Packer; Rich v Long [2007] NSWSC 1290; BC200709765 (extension pending delivery of a prior potentially relevant judgment); Weston v Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1318; BC200709974 contrast with Weston v Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd (2011) 83 ACSR 206; [2011] NSWSC 433; BC201103172 (need for further time to make further investigations and assessments and to secure litigation funding may provide “good reason” to grant a limited extension period).
These examples illustrate some of the factors likely to influence the exercise of the extension power:
the absence of material prejudice to other parties;
the absence of culpable delay;
the absence of present ability to conduct the proceedings expeditiously; and
the likelihood that the efficient conduct of the proceedings will be materially influenced by particular contingencies.

Further examples, involving the application of these kinds of factors are contained in the notes at [1.12.5]–[1.12.40] , and also in the notes relating to the analogous discretion to extend time for appeal (see [51.16.5]–[51.16.20] ). Exercise of the power to extend time involves particular difficulty where the extension will permit continuation of the proceedings notwithstanding the expiry of a relevant limitation period. In such cases there is no presumption against exercise of the extension power, but the applicant still bears the onus of establishing sufficient reason for the extension: Tolcher v Gordon (2005) 53 ACSR 442; 23 ACLC 798; [2005] NSWCA 135; BC200502708 (difficulty in effecting service — solicitor’s default — successful application to set aside default dismissal). A deliberate unexplained decision not to act within the relevant period may readily justify refusal of an application for extension Pell v Hodges [2007] NSWCA 234; BC200707569 at [30] (application for extension of time for service — 19 months after the expiration of limitation period — apparently deliberate delay in effecting service — inadequate reasons for delay — application refused); Arthur Andersen Corporateion Finance Pty Ltd v Buzzle Operations Pty Ltd (in liq) [2009] NSWCA 104; BC200903847 at [28]–[34] (liquidator’s deliberate delay — uncertainty in relation to funding and recoverability of damages — substituted service more than 12 months after limitation period — extension refused).

level.toc-caption: [6.2.17] Notice of application for extension of time

p.text: Legislation cited in [6.2.17] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 12.11(1)(e).

heading.title: Notice of application for extension of time

p.text: Where an extension order has been made, and service effected, UCPR r 12.11(1)(e) permits a defendant to apply for the discharge of the order. That express entitlement implies that an order extending time for service may be made without prior notice. Despite that implication, differing views have been expressed about the desirability of prior notice: Rich v Long [2008] NSWSC 487; BC200803664 at [31] per Young CJ in Eq (notice should be given); contrast Weston v Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd [2009] NSWSC 321; BC200903091 at [19]–[25] per Barrett J (notice neither required nor necessary). Irrespective of the absence of any formal requirement for notice, exercise of the power does require consideration of any potential prejudice to the defendant. Relevant considerations will include the actual or imminent expiry of any limitation period and of the original period for valid service of the originating process: Weston v Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd [2009] NSWSC 321; BC200903091 at [13]–[18] per Barrett J.

An application to extend the period for validity of service set out in UCPR r 6.2(4)(a) for matters in the Possessions List may be made to the Registrar, Common Law Case Management without filing or serving a notice of motion. Applications must be in writing and set out the extended period of time that is sought, and the reason why an extension of time is required. If the extension of time is required as a result of a stay pending an investigation by an Ombudsman then an affidavit is not required. In all other cases an affidavit must be provided. Applications can be submitted by email: see Practice Note SC CL 6 paras 52 and 53. The procedure contemplated in SC CL 6 implies that an applicant for an extension of time is not required to give notice to the other parties.
Legislation cited in [6.2.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 1.

This rule does not apply to proceedings in class 1 (environmental planning and protection appeals), 2 (local government and miscellaneous appeals and applications) or 3 (land tenure, valuation, ratings and compensation matters) of the Land and Environment Court: see Sch 1 to UCPR. It does apply to proceedings in class 4 (environmental planning and protection and development contract civil enforcement) of the Land and Environment Court: see also Sch 1 of the UCPR.

In the District Court if the claims are limited to a debt, liquidated demand or motor vehicle damage claims within UCPR r 14.13(2), statements of claim may be served up to 6 months from filing: Practice Note DC (Civil) No 14.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.3] r 6.3 Where statement of claim required (cf SCR Part 4, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Where statement of claim required (cf SCR Part 4, rule 2)

p.text: Proceedings of the following kinds must be commenced by statement of claim:
proceedings on a claim for relief in relation to a debt or other liquidated claim,
proceedings on a claim for relief in relation to a tort,
proceedings on a claim based on an allegation of fraud,
proceedings on a claim for damages for breach of duty (however arising) and the damages claimed consist of or include:
damages in respect of the death of any person, or
damages in respect of personal injuries to any person, or
damages in respect of damage to any property,
proceedings on a claim for relief in relation to a trust, other than an express trust wholly in writing,
proceedings on a claim for possession of land,
proceedings on a claim for relief under the Property (Relationships) Act 1984 ,
proceedings on a claim for relief in relation to the publication of defamatory matter.
[r 3 am Amendment 5 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[2], effective 1 January 2006]

level.toc-caption: [6.3.5] Special procedure for debts or other liquidated demands

heading.title: Special procedure for debts or other liquidated demands

p.text: Characterisation of a claim as one for a “debt or other liquidated demand” was of greater practical significance under earlier rules of court that limited either or both of the default judgment procedure and the requirement for verification of defences, to proceedings involving such claims. The special procedures which applied to such proceedings reflected the courts desire to prevent unmeritorious defences and to limit the expense involved in prosecuting proceedings where defendants proved to be insolvent: Bailey v Bailey (1884) 13 QBD 855 per Grove J. That desire ultimately resulted in the expansion of the verification requirement (this occurred in 1983 in the Supreme Court Rules) and a consequential availability of the default judgment procedure in Pt 16 r 3, irrespective of the nature of the claim, whenever any defendant fails to comply with the requirement for verification. Several other provisions of the rules also provide for the entry of judgment in relation to proceedings involving liquidated claims: see [6.17.5].

It has been said that “whenever the amount to which the plaintiff is entitled … can be ascertained by calculation or fixed by any scale of charges, or other positive data, it is … liquidated”: Odgers on Pleading and Practice, 5th ed, at p 41. This proposition was approved by Knox CJ and Starke J of the High Court in Spain v Union Steamship Co of NZ Ltd (1923) 32 CLR 138 (a claim to recover “reasonable expenses” was a liquidated claim). The essential concept is also illustrated by Palles CB in Stephenson v Weir (1879) LR Ir 369 (in a passage that was followed in Whelan v Kelly (1884) 14 LR Ir 387 at 373) as follows:

“When it was said that an action of debt would lie only for a sum certain, it was sufficient that the sum should be capable of being ascertained by a jury by positive data and not merely measured by opinion or conjecture. In the present case, for instance, when the value of the work was ascertained, the sum to be recovered became definite, and the case would not be like one of assault in which there were not any certain date to fix the amount of damages.”

But these illustrations do little more than state a very general proposition. In fact numerous cases have referred to the difficulty of ascertaining the true meaning of the phrase “debt or liquidated demand”. Its basic meaning can be established historically, but changes and developments in the law have made application of the original definition difficult. In Alexander v Ajax Insurance Co Ltd [1956] VLR 436; [1956] ALR 1077 Sholl J traced the history of the phrase and concluded that in 1851 it covered any claim:
for which the action of debt would lie;

for which an indebitatus (or “common”) count would lie — including those cases formerly covered by the quantum meruit or quantam valebat counts, notwithstanding that the only agreement implied between the parties in such cases was for payment at a “reasonable” rate;

for which covenant or special assumpsit, would lie, provided that the claim was for a specific amount not involving in the calculation thereof elements whose selection would depend on the opinion of a jury.
See also Farwell LJ in Lagos v Grunwaldt [1910] 1 KB 41 at 48 .

level.toc-caption: [6.3.15] Liquidated claims — instalment contracts for the sale of land

heading.title: Liquidated claims — instalment contracts for the sale of land

p.text: The difficulty of drawing the distinction between liquidated and unliquidated claims may be illustrated by reference to proceedings concerning instalment contracts for the sale of land. Although breach of the contract sounds in damages, they may be either liquidated or unliquidated — depending upon the precise claim. There was at one time a tendency to say that instalments of purchase money could not be recovered by a common law action for liquidated damages because the purchase price was payable for the land, not for the promise to convey. Since the price was only recoverable on conveyance of the property, the claim was necessarily to be regarded as an unliquidated claim for damages: Laird v Pim (1841) 7 M & W 474; 151 ER 852; Leader v Tod-Heatly [1891] WN 38 . More recent authorities regard instalment contracts for the purchase of land as requiring the purchaser to pay specific amounts on fixed dates in exchange for a promise to convey subsequently, and at the risk that it may not ultimately be performed: Ruwald v Halling (1927) 27 SR (NSW) 334 ; Reynolds v Fury [1921] VLR 14 ; McDonald v Dennys Lascelles Ltd (1933) 48 CLR 457; [1933] ALR 381 ; Automatic Fire Sprinklers Pty Ltd v Watson (1946) 72 CLR 435 per Dixon J at 464. On this analysis the claim for the unpaid instalments is a liquidated claim.

Cases where it has been held that the claim was a debt or liquidated demand include: Duffy v De Rozzoli (1887) 8 LR (NSW) 153; 3 WN (NSW) 132 (an action will lie in the district court on a judgment recovered in the Supreme Court); Grant v Easton (1883) 13 QBD 302 (an action on a foreign judgment); Beech v Potter (1904) 29 VLR 830 (claim for amount due for use and occupation of premises); Workman, Clark & Co Ltd v Lloyd Brazileno [1908] 1 KB 968 (claim for instalment of purchase price of ship); Lagos v Grunwaldt [1910] 1 KB 41 (claim on a quantum meruit for professional work as solicitor); Mallinson v Scottish Australian Investment Co Ltd (1920) 28 CLR 66; 26 ALR 225 (claim to recover additional wages); Spain v Union Steamship Co of New Zealand Ltd (1923) 32 CLR 138 (action by ship's captain to recover the expenses incurred in connection with a Court of Marine Enquiry); Ruwald v Halling (1927) 27 SR (NSW) 334 ; McDonald v Dennys Lascelles Ltd (1933) 48 CLR 457; [1933] ALR 381 (claims for instalment on contract for purchase of land); Segur v Franklin (1934) 34 SR (NSW) 67; 51 WN (NSW) 31 (claim by arbitrator on a quantum meruit); Automatic Fire Sprinklers Pty Ltd v Watson (1946) 72 CLR 435 (claim for wages by employee following unauthorised dismissal); GL Baker Ltd v Barclays Bank Ltd [1956] 3 All ER 519 (claim for conversion of a sum of money); Latec Finance Pty Ltd v Wilkins (1962) 1 DCR (NSW) 29 (claim calculated in accordance with Hire Purchase Agreements Act 1941–1957 s 5, for breach of the hire purchase agreement); Lombard Australia Ltd v Atkins (No 1) (1963) 1 DCR (NSW) 25 (claim to recover amount determined by reference to the Hire-Purchase Act 1960 s 15(2)).

It has been held in the following cases that the amount claimed was not a debt or liquidated demand: Knight v Abbott (1882) 10 QBD 11 and Abbey Panel & Sheet Metal Co Ltd v Barson Products [1948] 1 KB 493 (a claim for unliquidated damages is not made into a liquidated demand merely by naming a definite figure); Bailey v Bailey (1884) 13 QBD 855 (claim for arrears of alimony); Alexander v Ajax Insurance Co Ltd [1956] VLR 436; [1956] ALR 1077 (a claim for an indemnity under an insurance policy).
Legislation cited in [6.3.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 16.6(1)(b).

A claim for interest, including a claim for statutory interest of the kinds specified in the Dictionary definition of “interest up to judgment”, is a claim for a liquidated demand for the purpose of the UCPR. This includes a claim for interest under CPA s 100. UCPR r 16.6(1)(b) specifically authorises default judgment to be entered in an amount that includes an amount for interest up to the date of the judgment.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.4] r 6.4 Where summons required (cf SCR Part 4, rule 2, 2A and 3)

leg:heading.title: Where summons required (cf SCR Part 4, rule 2, 2A and 3)

p.text: Proceedings of the following kinds must be commenced by summons:
proceedings in which there is no defendant,
proceedings on an appeal or application for leave to appeal, other than proceedings assigned to the Court of Appeal,
proceedings before the Supreme Court in the exercise of its jurisdiction under section 69 of the Supreme Court Act 1970,
proceedings for preliminary discovery or inspection under Part 5,
proceedings on a stated case,
proceedings on an application for approval under section 75 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 of an agreement for the compromise or settlement of a claim,
proceedings on an application for a transfer order under Part 9 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005,
proceedings on an application for the removal or transfer of proceedings to the court under any Act, other than an application for a transfer order under Part 9 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005,
proceedings (other than proceedings on a claim for damages) on any application made under any Act (other than the Civil Procedure Act 2005),
proceedings on an application to the court under any Act, other than:
proceedings on an application under the Supreme Court Act 1970, the District Court Act 1973 or the Local Court Act 2007, and
proceedings on an application that may properly be made in existing proceedings.
any other proceedings that, pursuant to these rules or any other rules of court, are required to be commenced by summons.
[subr (1) am Amendment 23 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 7 November 2008 ; Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[2], effective 6 July 2009 ; Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[2], effective 8 October 2009]
Proceedings of the following kinds may be commenced by summons, except where the application is made in proceedings that have been commenced in the court:
proceedings on an application for a writ of habeas corpus ad subjiciendum,
proceedings on an application for an order for the custody of a minor,
proceedings on an application for an order for the appointment of a tutor of a person under legal incapacity,
proceedings on an application for a declaration of right,
proceedings on an application for an injunction,
proceedings on an application for the appointment of a receiver,
proceedings on an application for an order for the detention, custody or preservation of property,
proceedings on a claim for relief for trespass to land.
If proceedings have already been commenced, the application should be made by motion: see rule 18.1 .
[subr (2) am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[15]–[17], effective 15 August 2005]
Proceedings in the Supreme Court that the plaintiff intends to be entered in the Commercial List or the Technology and Construction List are to be commenced by summons.
Proceedings:
in which the sole or principal question at issue is, or is likely to be, one of:
the construction of an Act or a Commonwealth Act, or
the construction of an instrument made under an Act or a Commonwealth Act, or
the construction of a deed, will, contract or other document, or
some other question of law, or
in which there is unlikely to be a substantial dispute of fact,
are amongst those which are appropriate to be commenced by summons unless the plaintiff considers the proceedings more appropriate to be commenced by statement of claim.
[subr (4) insrt Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[18], effective 15 August 2005]
[r 6.4 am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[14], effective 15 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.5] r 6.5 Proceedings wrongly commenced by statement of claim (cf SCR Part 4, rule 2B)

leg:heading.title: Proceedings wrongly commenced by statement of claim (cf SCR Part 4, rule 2B)

p.text: Proceedings that have been commenced by statement of claim when they should have been commenced by summons are nevertheless, and for all purposes, taken to have been duly commenced as from the date of the filing of the statement of claim, and may be continued accordingly.

Despite subrule (1), the court may order the proceedings to be continued, as if they had been commenced by summons and as if any pleadings filed in the proceedings had been filed as affidavits, and may also make such orders as it thinks fit for the future conduct of the proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.6] r 6.6 Proceedings wrongly commenced by summons (cf SCR Part 5, rule 11)

leg:heading.title: Proceedings wrongly commenced by summons (cf SCR Part 5, rule 11)

p.text: Proceedings that have been commenced by summons when they should have been commenced by statement of claim are nevertheless, and for all purposes, taken to have been duly commenced as from the date of the filing of the summons.
Despite subrule (1), the court may order that the proceedings continue on pleadings.
On or after making such an order, the court:
may order that any affidavits stand as pleadings, or
may make orders for the filing of a statement of claim or other pleadings.

After a statement of claim is filed pursuant to an order referred to in subrule (3)(b), the proceedings are to continue, subject to any other order of the court, as if commenced by statement of claim.
The court may, on the first or any later day of hearing:
hear and determine the proceedings or any claim in the proceedings, and
make such order or give such judgment as the nature of the case requires.
Legislation cited in [6.7.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 22, 90.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.1.

This rule complements CPA ss 22 and 90 and permits the court to give a judgment or make an order notwithstanding the absence of a specific claim in any pleading. It may be utilised, for example, where evidence has been admitted without objection and establishes an entitlement beyond that relied on in the pleadings: Dare v Pulham (1982) 148 CLR 658; 44 ALR 117; BC8200139 , applied in American Foods Pty Ltd v Beson [2000] NSWSC 535; BC200003866 (judgment entered on the basis of an agreement different to that pleaded where the case had been conducted in this way from the outset). See also UCPR r 36.1 , which empowers the court “at any stage of the proceedings” to “give such judgment, or make such order, as the nature of the case requires, whether or not the claim for relief extending to that judgment or order is included in any statement of claim or summons”.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.8] r 6.8 Originating process for recovery of land to be served on occupier (cf SCR Part 7, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Originating process for recovery of land to be served on occupier (cf SCR Part 7, rule 8)

p.text: If, when proceedings for possession of land are commenced, a person (the occupier) not joined as a defendant is in occupation of the whole or any part of the land, the plaintiff:
must state in the originating process that the plaintiff does not seek to disturb the occupier’s occupation of the land, or
must serve the originating process on the occupier together with a notice to the effect that:
the occupier may apply to the court for an order that the occupier be added as a defendant, and
if the occupier does not so apply within 10 days after service, the occupier may be evicted under a judgment entered in the occupier’s absence.

For the purposes of subrule (1), documents may be served on the occupier personally or by leaving the documents on the land concerned addressed to the occupier by name or addressed simply “to the occupier”.

If originating process is amended by the addition of a claim for possession of land, the time at which proceedings for possession of that land are commenced is taken, for the purposes of subrule (1), to be the time at which the amendment is made.
The approved form is Form 5 : Notice to occupier.
Legislation cited in [6.8.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.8, r 6.24(2).

A writ of possession cannot issue against an occupier unless the plaintiff proves service of a notice in compliance with this rule: see r 36.8 . Personal service on each “occupier” is permitted, but not required. Service is sufficiently effected by leaving the relevant documents “on the land”, addressed simply “to the occupier”: National Australia Bank v Nikolaidis (2011) 15 BPR 29,287; [2011] NSWSC 506; BC201103982 at [19] . An occupier who has been served with a notice under this rule may apply to be joined as a defendant: see r 6.24(2) .

The purpose of the notice requirement in this rule is to ensure that the people who actually have a right to occupy the property have an opportunity to propound that right, by intervention in the proceedings: Kerr v Sheriff of New South Wales (1996) 9 BPR 16,215; BC9600243 at 3 per Young J; Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v PA Wright & Sons Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Giles J, 50198/96, 3 July 1997, unreported, BC9702853) at 6; Commonwealth Development Bank v Windermere Pastoral Co Pty Ltd [2000] NSWSC 421; BC200002689 at [24] ; Yeshiva Properties No 1 Pty Ltd v Lubavitch Mazal Pty Ltd (No 2) [2003] NSWSC 752; BC200304809 at [12] ; Secure Funding Pty Ltd v Coughlin (2009) 74 NSWLR 687; [2009] NSWSC 384; BC200903922 at [11] ; National Australia Bank v Nikolaidis, above at [10]–[12]. The rule reduces the potential for collusion (for example between a mortgagor and mortgagee) to deprive an occupier of possession of property: National Australia Bank v Nikolaidis, above at [11] (obiter). But the rule is also of potential benefit to a plaintiff. Compliance with the notice requirement of the rule will facilitate a plaintiff becoming apprised of, and meeting in a timely and cost effective manner, any adverse claims by occupiers of the property: National Australia Bank v Nikolaidis, above at [16] citing Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v PA Wright & Sons Pty Ltd, above at p 11.

Provided the required notice is served on the “occupier” (the person with the right to occupy) it is not necessary that it also be served on their dependants: Kerr v Sheriff of New South Wales, above at 3 per Young J; Secure Funding Pty Ltd v Coughlin, above at [11].

There is no specific definition of what constitutes relevant “occupation” of the property for the purposes of the rule. Nevertheless there are some clear categories of persons that have been accepted as regarded as not being “in occupation” for the purposes of the rule. These include:
individual members of the family of a tenant or other occupier: National Commercial Banking Corporation of Australia Ltd v MRM Holdings Pty Ltd (1983) 3 BPR 9339; (1984) NSW ConvR 55-210 ;

children residing with their parents: Secure Funding Pty Ltd v Coughlin (2009) 74 NSWLR 687; [2009] NSWSC 384; BC200903922 at [7]–[14] ; NSW Trustee and Guardian v Colin Edward James Schneider [2011] NSWSC 424; BC201102997 at [27] ;
friends or visitors of tenants or “occupiers”: Kerr v Sheriff of New South Wales (1996) 9 BPR 16,215; BC9600243 ;

non-resident teachers, students or clients: Bankstown Airport Ltd v Noor Al Houda Islamic College Pty Ltd [2002] ANZ ConvR 413; (2003) NSW ConvR 56–038 at 58,566; [2002] NSWSC 193; BC200200923 at [62]–[70] per Young CJ in Eq (obiter).

A person’s employee may be “in occupation” for the purposes of the rule. The proper characterisation of an employee’s rights as “occupier” will depend on whether or not they occupy the property as a part of their remuneration or, on the other hand, merely on behalf of their employer: Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v PA Wright & Sons Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Giles J, 50198/96, 3 July 1997, unreported, BC9702853) at 7–8 citing inter alia HA Warner Pty Ltd v Williams (1946) 73 CLR 421 at 429; 20 ALJR 414 per Dixon J. Because of the difficulty of characterising the nature of an employee’s potential rights as an occupier of the property, it is prudent to ensure they are given notice of any proceedings for possession: Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v PA Wright & Sons Pty Ltd, above at 9.

The plain, but not specifically stated, intention of the rule is that the originating process should be served on the occupier within a reasonable time after the commencement of the proceedings. But late notice, provided it has in fact been given in sufficient time to afford the occupier an opportunity to apply to be joined in the proceedings, would still be likely to constitute relevant compliance with the rule: National Australia Bank v Nikolaidis (2011) 15 BPR 29,287; [2011] NSWSC 506; BC201103982 at [18] , [24]–[25].

The court may exercise the power conferred by CPA s 14 to dispense with, or temporarily suspend, the requirement for service of a “notice to occupier” in an appropriate case. Appropriate circumstances may include (i) where the occupiers are already aware of the possession proceedings and have had ample opportunity to participate in them: Yeshiva Properties No 1 Pty Ltd v Lubavitch Mazal Pty Ltd (No 2) [2003] NSWSC 752; BC200304809 at [13]–[16] , (ii) where successful mediation or settlement of the proceedings is a real prospect: National Australia Bank v Nikolaidis (2011) 15 BPR 29,287; [2011] NSWSC 506; BC201103982 at [29] , or where there is a substantial preliminary challenge to the basis of the plaintiff’s claim for possession: National Australia Bank v Nikolaidis, above at [38]–[40].
Legislation cited in [6.8.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.8(2).

For documents to be “left on the land” for the purposes of r 6.8(2) it is not necessary that they be placed on the ground or upon some other part of the premises which could be equated to “land”. The subrule is complied with if the documents are left with a person in the premises on the land, particularly where it appears that that person had some right to be on the land. If the documents are left with a person who is on the land and who at that time had an apparent or legal right to be there, they are “left on the land” and service within the meaning of the rule has been effected: Smith v Westpac Banking Corp (NSWSC, Rolfe J, 19 September 1991, unreported, BC9101556).
Legislation cited in [6.8.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 4.7A.
Any originating process planning possession of land, and any judgement or order for possession, must include a description of the proper title of the land : see UCPR r 4.7A .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 6.8A] r 6.8A Originating process for proceedings to be entered in Possession List

leg:heading.title: Originating process for proceedings to be entered in Possession List

p.text: The originating process in proceedings in the Common Law Division of the Supreme Court that are to be entered in The Possession List is to have a coversheet in the approved form.
[r 6.8A insrt Amendment 30 of 2009 Sch 1[1], effective 11 December 2009]

Plaintiffs in proceedings in the Possession List of the Supreme Court must attach a multi-language coversheet to the originating process. The coversheet must give defendants general information about the proceedings. For the form of coversheet to Statement of Claim see Form 93 reproduced at [452,820] in vol 3.
